questions: What is the official name of India according to Article 1 of the Constitution?
Which Article guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons?
What is abolished by Article 17 of the Constitution?
What are the key ideals mentioned in the Preamble of the Constitution of India?
Under which Article can Parliament alter the boundaries, area, or name of an existing State?
According to Article 24, children below what age are prohibited from working in hazardous industries like factories or mines?
What is the significance of Article 21 in the Indian Constitution?
Article 15 prohibits discrimination on certain grounds. However, which groups can the State make special provisions for under this Article?
Which Article allows Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship and override previous articles on citizenship (Articles 5 to 10)?
What restrictions can the State impose on the right to freedom of speech under Article 19(2)?
answers: The official name of India according to Article 1 of the Constitution is "India, that is Bharat."
Article 14 guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons.
Article 17 of the Constitution abolishes "untouchability" and forbids its practice in any form.
The key ideals mentioned in the Preamble of the Constitution of India are Justice, Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity.
Parliament can alter the boundaries, area, or name of an existing State under Article 3 of the Constitution of India.
Children below the age of fourteen years are prohibited from working in hazardous industries like factories or mines.

Article 21 of the Indian Constitution guarantees the right to life and personal liberty, stating that no person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law. It is a fundamental right that protects individuals against arbitrary actions of the state and has been interpreted to include a wide range of rights such as the right to privacy, right to a fair trial, right to livelihood, and right to a clean environment.

The State can make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes of citizens, Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and economically weaker sections of citizens (other than the classes mentioned above), including in matters of admission to educational institutions and reservation in services under the State.
Article 11 allows Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship and override previous articles on citizenship (Articles 5 to 10).

The State can impose reasonable restrictions on the right to freedom of speech and expression in the interests of the sovereignty and integrity of India, the security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, or in relation to contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence.

questions: If my car is stolen, what case will it be in law?
If I am arrested without a warrant, is that legal?
If someone denies me a job because of my caste, is that allowed?
If the government takes my land for a project, can I stop it?
If my child is forced to work in a factory, is that legal?
If I am stopped from speaking at a protest, is that against my rights?
If a religious place stops me from entering because I'm a woman, is that constitutional?
If I change my religion, can the government stop me?
If the police torture someone in custody, what right is being violated?
If I'm denied admission to a public university because I'm from a backward community, can I do something?
answers: If your car is stolen, it will be a case of theft under criminal law.

Yes, you can be arrested without a warrant if the arrest is made according to procedure established by law. However, after arrest, you must be informed of the grounds for arrest, allowed to consult a legal practitioner of your choice, and produced before the nearest magistrate within 24 hours (excluding travel time), and cannot be detained beyond that period without magistrate’s authority.
No, it is not allowed. Denying a job to a citizen on the grounds of caste is prohibited.

You cannot stop the government from acquiring your land for a public purpose if the acquisition is done in accordance with the law in force. However, if your land is under personal cultivation and within the ceiling limit, the State cannot acquire it unless compensation at not less than market value is provided for the land, building, or structure.
No, it is not legal. No child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment.

If you are stopped from speaking at a protest, it may be against your right to freedom of speech and expression under Article 19(1)(a) of the Constitution of India, unless the restriction is reasonable and falls under the exceptions provided by law, such as public order, decency, or morality.
No, it is not constitutional. Denying entry to a religious place solely on the ground of sex violates the right to equality and non-discrimination guaranteed under the Constitution of India.

No, the government cannot stop you from changing your religion. You have the freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate any religion, subject only to public order, morality, and health.

The right being violated is the protection of life and personal liberty, as no person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law. Torture in custody violates this right.

No, you cannot be denied admission to a public university solely because you are from a backward community. The Constitution prohibits denial of admission on grounds only of religion, race, caste, or language. In fact, the State can make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes, including reservation in admissions. If you are denied admission solely for being from a backward community, it is unconstitutional and you can challenge this denial.

questions: How does Newton define 'quantity of motion' and how is it distinct from 'force'?
According to Newton, what are the three laws of motion and how do they apply in celestial mechanics?
How does Newton derive Kepler's Second Law (equal areas in equal times) from his laws of motion and gravitation?
How does Newton demonstrate that gravity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between two masses?
What is Newton's argument for why gravitational force must act on all masses universally?
How does Newton explain the perturbation of planetary orbits due to other planets?
What mathematical tools did Newton use in Principia that were precursors to calculus, and why didn't he use standard calculus notation?
How does Newton use the concept of centripetal force to explain orbital motion?
How does Newton handle motion in resisting media, such as air or fluids?
In what way does Newton's notion of absolute space and time differ from relative motion, and how does it support his laws?
Who was the grandfather of Isaac Newton?
Do we know any other descent of Isaac Newton apart from his grandfather?
answers: Newton defines 'quantity of motion' as the measure of motion in a body, calculated by multiplying its mass by its velocity (momentum). It is distinct from 'force' because 'force' refers to the action that changes the state of motion of a body, while 'quantity of motion' describes the current state of motion (momentum) the body possesses.

Newton’s three laws of motion are:

1. First Law (Law of Inertia): An object remains at rest or in uniform motion in a straight line unless acted upon by an external force.
2. Second Law (Law of Acceleration): The force acting on an object is equal to the mass of the object multiplied by its acceleration (F = ma).
3. Third Law (Action-Reaction): For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.

In celestial mechanics, these laws explain planetary motion: planets move in orbits due to inertia (First Law), gravitational force causes their acceleration (Second Law), and the mutual gravitational attraction between celestial bodies demonstrates action and reaction (Third Law).

Newton derives Kepler's Second Law (equal areas in equal times) using his laws of motion and universal gravitation by showing that a planet orbiting the Sun experiences a central force directed toward the Sun (gravity). This central force produces zero torque about the Sun, so the planet's angular momentum is conserved. Conservation of angular momentum means the line joining the planet and the Sun sweeps out equal areas in equal times, which is Kepler's Second Law.

Newton demonstrates that gravity is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between two masses by formulating the law of universal gravitation, which states that the gravitational force (F) between two masses (m₁ and m₂) is directly proportional to the product of their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance (r) between their centers. Mathematically, F = G * (m₁ * m₂) / r², where G is the gravitational constant. This relationship shows that as the distance between the masses increases, the gravitational force decreases by the square of that distance.

Gravitational force must act on all masses universally because mass is the property that causes and experiences gravity; if gravity did not act equally on all masses, the laws of motion and the principle of universal gravitation would be violated, leading to inconsistencies in the observed motions of celestial and terrestrial bodies. Universal gravitation ensures that every mass attracts every other mass with a force proportional to their masses and inversely proportional to the square of the distance between them, maintaining consistency in the behavior of objects throughout the universe.

Newton explains the perturbation of planetary orbits as the result of gravitational forces exerted by other planets. Each planet attracts every other planet according to the law of universal gravitation, causing deviations from perfect elliptical orbits. These mutual gravitational interactions lead to changes in orbital elements such as eccentricity, inclination, and orientation, resulting in complex, perturbed paths rather than simple ellipses.

Newton used mathematical tools such as the method of "first and last ratios" and geometric arguments involving limits and infinitesimals in Principia. These methods are precursors to calculus, allowing him to analyze motion, change, and areas under curves. He did not use standard calculus notation because, at the time, calculus notation (such as Leibniz’s dx and dy) had not yet been widely adopted or standardized. Newton preferred geometric proofs to make his work more rigorous and acceptable to the mathematical community of his era, which was skeptical of the new and not yet formalized calculus methods.

Newton explains orbital motion by stating that a centripetal force acts continuously on a body moving in a curved path, such as a planet orbiting the Sun. This centripetal force pulls the body toward the center of its orbit, counteracting its inertia, and prevents it from moving in a straight line. In planetary motion, gravity provides the necessary centripetal force, keeping planets in stable elliptical orbits around the Sun.

Newton handles motion in resisting media, such as air or fluids, by incorporating resistive forces (like drag or friction) that act opposite to the direction of motion. These resistive forces are added to Newton’s second law (F = ma) as negative terms. The magnitude of the resistive force typically depends on the velocity of the object—proportional to velocity for low speeds (linear drag) and proportional to the square of velocity for higher speeds (quadratic drag). The net force on the object is the sum of all applied forces minus the resistive force, resulting in a reduced acceleration and eventual terminal velocity when the resistive force balances the driving force.

Newton's notion of absolute space and time asserts that space and time exist independently and uniformly, providing a fixed, unchanging reference frame. Absolute space is the same everywhere and always, unaffected by objects or events, while absolute time flows uniformly regardless of anything external. In contrast, relative motion describes the movement of objects only in relation to each other, not to any fixed background.

Newton's absolute space and time support his laws by providing a universal frame in which his laws of motion—especially inertia and acceleration—can be defined objectively. This allows for the distinction between true motion (motion relative to absolute space) and apparent motion (motion relative to other objects), ensuring the consistency and universality of Newton's laws.
Isaac Newton's grandfather was Robert Newton.
No, Isaac Newton did not have any descendants. He never married and had no children, so he left no direct lineage.

questions: What is the grace period for premium payment?
Are the medical expenses for an organ donor covered under this policy?
answers: The Grace Period for payment of the premium shall be thirty days.

Yes, the medical expenses for an organ donor's hospitalization during the policy period for harvesting the organ donated to an Insured Person are covered, provided the following conditions are met:
*   The organ donation confirms to the Transplantation of Human Organs Act 1994 (and its amendments from time to time).
*   The organ is used for an Insured Person and the Insured Person has been medically advised to undergo an organ transplant.
*   The Medical Expenses shall be incurred in respect of the organ donor as an in-patient in a Hospital.

However, the following are excluded:
*   Pre-hospitalization Medical Expenses or Post-Hospitalization Medical Expenses of the organ donor.
*   Costs directly or indirectly associated with the acquisition of the donor's organ.
*   Medical Expenses where the organ transplant is experimental or investigational.
*   Any medical treatment or complication in respect of the donor, consequent to harvesting.
*   Any expenses related to organ transportation or preservation.

The payable items are:
*   **Prosthetic device:** Payable, if implanted during the hip replacement surgery or if it is a medically necessary artificial device/prosthesis required immediately following surgery as part of recuperation.

The following items are not payable:
*   **Walker:** Not payable, as walking aids are listed as "Not Payable" and are considered convenience items.
*   **Lumbar belt:** Not payable, as it is only payable for cases who have undergone surgery of the lumbar spine, not a hip replacement surgery.

An insured's child, if unmarried, unemployed, and dependent, and between 18 and 26 years of age, is eligible for coverage.

The process for this specific scenario is as follows:

**Notification of Claim:**
*   For emergency hospitalization, notify the TPA in writing within 24 hours from the date of emergency hospitalization or before discharge, whichever is earlier.
*   For planned hospitalization, notify the TPA in writing at least 48 hours prior to admission.

**Procedure for Cashless Claims:**
*   Cashless facility is available for treatment in network hospitals, subject to pre-authorization by the TPA.
*   Upon admission, produce the ID card issued by the TPA at the Hospital Insurance-desk.
*   Complete and send the cashless request form to the TPA for pre-authorization.
*   The TPA will issue a pre-authorization letter after verification.
*   At the time of discharge, verify and sign the discharge papers and final bill, and pay for non-medical and inadmissible expenses.

**Procedure for Reimbursement of Claims:**
*   For non-network hospitals, payment must be made upfront.
*   Submit the necessary original documents to the TPA within 15 days from the date of discharge from the hospital.

**Required Documents (for reimbursement):**
*   Duly completed claim form
*   Photo ID and Age proof
*   Health Card, policy copy, photo ID, KYC documents
*   Attending medical practitioner's / surgeon's certificate regarding diagnosis/nature of operation performed, along with date of diagnosis, investigation test reports, supported by the prescription from the attending medical practitioner
*   Medical history of the patient as recorded (all previous consultation papers indicating history and treatment details for current ailment), bills (including break up of charges) and payment receipts duly supported by the prescription from attending medical practitioner/hospital
*   Discharge certificate/summary from the hospital
*   Original final Hospital bill with detailed break-up with all original deposit and final payment receipt
*   Original invoice with payment receipt and implant stickers for all implants used during Surgeries (e.g., lens sticker and Invoice in cataract Surgery, stent invoice and sticker in Angioplasty Surgery)
*   All original diagnostic reports (including imaging and laboratory) along with Medical Practitioner's prescription and invoice / bill with receipt from diagnostic center
*   All original medicine / pharmacy bills along with the Medical Practitioner's prescription
*   MLC / FIR copy in Accidental cases only
*   Copy of death summary and copy of death certificate (in death claims only)
*   Pre and post-operative imaging reports
*   Copy of indoor case papers with nursing sheet detailing medical history of the Insured Person, treatment details and the Insured Person's progress
*   Cheque copy with name of proposer printed on the cheque leaf or copy of the first page of the bank passbook or the bank statement not later than 3 months.

For Intra Operative Neuro Monitoring (IONM), the expenses are limited up to the limit specified in the Policy Schedule or Certificate of Insurance per policy period for claims involving Intra Operative Neuro Monitoring.

For ICU care, the charges for accommodation in ICU/ICCU/HDU are covered up to the category/limit specified in the Policy Schedule/Certificate of Insurance or actual expenses incurred, whichever is less. A hospital in a city with a population of over 1,000,000 must have at least 15 in-patient beds to meet the definition of a hospital. The Intensive Care Unit (ICU) is defined as an identified section, ward, or wing of a hospital under constant supervision of a dedicated medical practitioner(s), specially equipped for continuous monitoring and treatment of critical patients.

To add a newly-adopted child as a dependent, the policyholder must follow the process for adding a member, which involves:

**Process for Addition:**
The child may be added to the Policy as an Insured Person during the Policy period, provided that:
*   The application for cover has been accepted by the insurer.
*   Additional premium on a pro-rata basis for the risk coverage duration for the Insured Person has been received by the insurer.
*   An endorsement confirming the addition of such person as an Insured Person has been issued by the insurer.
*   The policyholder must notify the insurer of all and any changes in the membership of the Policy occurring in a month on or before the last day of the succeeding month.
*   All endorsement requests shall be assessed by the underwriter, and where required, additional information/documents/premium may be requested.

**Circumstances for Refusal of Cover:**

**Eligibility Clause (B.3.b.iii on page 27):**
*   The child must be between the age of 91 days and 18 years.
*   Either or both parents must be covered concurrently under the policy. (A 3-year-old child meets the age criteria).

**Addition/Deletion Clause (12.A on page 28):**
*   If the application for cover is not accepted by the insurer.
*   If the additional pro-rata premium for the risk coverage duration is not received.
*   If an endorsement confirming the addition is not issued.

**Disclosure of Information/Fraud (V.A.2 on page 26 and 10 on page 28):**
*   The insurer may refuse cover if there is misrepresentation, misdescription, or non-disclosure of any material fact by the policyholder.
*   If any fraudulent means or devices are used to obtain any benefit under the policy.

The newborn's treatment expenses, including intensive care, are eligible for a claim from day 1, covered within the Family Sum Insured.

Pre-hospitalisation expenses of the same illness incurred 18 days before admission can be claimed under the **Pre-hospitalisation Medical Expenses Cover**. The policy covers "Actual Expenses Incurred" for a "Number of days-30" (Page 2, Base Covers), provided "Such Medical Expenses are incurred for the same condition for which the Insured Person's Hospitalisation was required" (Page 22, Clause III.A.3). Since the expenses occurred 18 days before admission and are for the same illness, they fall within this coverage.

Post-hospitalization diagnostics and pharmacy expenses for an infection developed 20 days after discharge cannot be claimed under the **Post-hospitalisation Medical Expenses Cover**. While these expenses occurred within the "Number of days-60" limit (Page 2, Base Covers), the policy specifies that such expenses must be "for the same condition for which the insured person's hospitalisation was required" (Page 22, Clause III.A.4). An infection developing after discharge is considered a new condition, not the same condition as the initial hospitalization, and therefore is not covered under this clause.

If a dependent child turns 27 during the policy period, their coverage terminates when they cease to be a dependent, which is upon turning 27, unless it is specifically agreed for continuation until the end of the policy period. This is consistent with the policy's eligibility criteria for children (up to age 26) and the termination clause for a dependent ceasing to be a dependent.

In case of admission to a room at rates exceeding the limits mentioned in the Policy Schedule/Certificate of Insurance, the reimbursement/payment of all associated medical expenses incurred at the Hospital shall be effected in the same proportion as the admissible rate per day bears to the actual rate per day of Room Rent.

The relevant clause is **Note 1: Proportionate Clause** under **III.A.1. In-patient Hospitalisation Expenses Cover** on page 22 of the policy document.

If a claim is partly rejected due to lack of required documentation, the company will intimate the deficiency. If the necessary claim documents are not met or are partially met within 10 working days of the first intimation, the company will send a maximum of 3 (three) reminders. The company may, at its sole discretion, deduct the amount for which deficiency is intimated and settle the claim if it is otherwise valid under the Policy.

The company will settle or reject a claim within 15 days from the date of receipt of the last necessary document. If an investigation is warranted, this period extends to 45 days from the date of receipt of the last necessary document.

If the company decides to reject a claim, it will communicate the grounds for rejection/repudiation in writing within 15 (thirty) days from the receipt of the final document(s) or investigation report. If the Insured Person wishes to contest a final rejection, they may, within 15 days from the date of receipt of the claims decision, represent to the company for reconsideration.

If the Insured Person is not satisfied with the redressal of the grievance through the company's channels (website, toll-free, email, courier, or branch grievance cell), they may contact the grievance officer. If still unsatisfied, the Insured Person can approach the office of the Insurance Ombudsman of the respective area/region as per Insurance Ombudsman Rules 2017, or lodge a grievance at the IRDAI Integrated Grievance Management System (https://igms.irda.gov.in/).

Yes, the claim is eligible under the **Day Care Treatment Cover**.

**Requirements for Day Care Treatment Cover (as per Clause II.A.10):**
Medical treatment and/or surgical procedure which is:
i. undertaken under General or Local Anesthesia in a hospital/day care centre in less than 24 hours because of technological advancement, and
ii. which would have otherwise required a hospitalisation of more than 24 hours. Treatment normally taken on an out-patient basis is not included in the scope of this definition.

For a hospital to qualify under this policy:

In towns having a population of less than 10,00,000, the hospital must have at least 10 in-patient beds.

In all other places (including metropolitan areas), the hospital must have at least 15 in-patient beds.

Additionally, for both, the hospital must:
*   Have qualified nursing staff under its employment round the clock.
*   Have qualified medical practitioner(s) in charge round the clock.
*   Have a fully equipped operation theatre of its own where surgical procedures are carried out.
*   Maintain daily records of patients and make them accessible to the insurance company's authorized personnel.

**Eligibility Criteria for Additions:**

*   **New Employee:** Must be a newly appointed employee of the policyholder.
*   **Spouse:** Must be a newly wedded spouse of the employee.
*   **Sibling:** Must be the employee's sibling, up to the age of 26 years, provided they are unmarried, unemployed, and dependent.

**Documentation Necessary to Process Additions:**

*   Application for cover accepted by the insurer.
*   Additional premium on a pro-rata basis applied on the risk coverage duration received by the insurer.
*   An endorsement confirming the addition issued by the insurer.
*   A written request for endorsement from the Policyholder.
*   Additional information/documents/premium may be requested by the underwriter.

According to the policy:
- **Medically Necessary Treatment (II. DEFINITIONS, 27)** must conform to the professional standards widely accepted in international medical practice or by the medical community in India.
- **Unproven/Experimental Treatment (II. DEFINITIONS, 43)** is defined as treatment, including drug experimental therapy, which is not based on established medical practice in India, or is treatment experimental or unproven.
- **Unproven Treatments (IV.PERMANENT EXCLUSIONS & WAITING PERIODS, 16)** are explicitly excluded. These are treatments, procedures, or supplies that lack significant medical documentation to support their effectiveness.

In the case of a multi-policy scenario, if the available coverage under the primary policy is less than the admissible claim amount, the procedure for claim settlement, coordination, and required documentation is as follows:

1.  **Claim Settlement:** The Insured Person can file for claim settlement as per their choice under any policy. The Insurer of that chosen policy will be treated as the primary Insurer.
2.  **Coordination:** If the available coverage under the primary policy is less than the admissible claim amount, the primary Insurer shall seek the details of other available policies of the policyholder and shall coordinate with other Insurers to ensure settlement of the balance amount.
3.  **Required Documentation:** A written request for the same must be submitted by the Insured Person.

Expenses related to hospitalization primarily for diagnostics and evaluation purposes, where no treatment was decided, are not claimable. This is explicitly stated under the "Standard Permanent Exclusions" section, specifically "Investigation & Evaluation (Code-Excl04)", which excludes:
i. Expenses related to any admission primarily for diagnostics and evaluation purposes only.
ii. Any diagnostic expenses which are not related or not incidental to the current diagnosis and treatment.

Similarly, an "AYUSH Day Care Centre" must be **registered with the local authorities**. Since the AYUSH hospital is not registered locally, it does not meet the policy's definition of a covered institution, regardless of whether it has qualified practitioners.

Yes, you can receive reimbursement for expenses not directly related to in-patient hospitalization, specifically for:

*   **Pre-hospitalisation Medical Expenses:** Covered on a reimbursement basis for a pre-defined number of days preceding hospitalization, provided the in-patient hospitalization claim is accepted and the expenses are for the same condition.

questions: I have raised a claim for hospitalization for Rs 200,000 with HDFC, and it's approved. My total expenses are Rs 250,000. Can I raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with you?
answers: No, you cannot raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with another insurer for the same hospitalization if the total claim has already been settled and approved for Rs 200,000 by HDFC. The policy covers expenses up to the sum insured per policy, and claims cannot be split or duplicated across insurers for the same event beyond the actual expenses incurred and the sum insured limits. If your sum insured with HDFC is Rs 200,000 and they have paid that amount, you cannot claim the excess with another insurer unless you have a separate policy with a different sum insured and follow contribution rules.

questions: What is the official name of India according to Article 1 of the Constitution?
Which Article guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons?
What is abolished by Article 17 of the Constitution?
What are the key ideals mentioned in the Preamble of the Constitution of India?
Under which Article can Parliament alter the boundaries, area, or name of an existing State?
According to Article 24, children below what age are prohibited from working in hazardous industries like factories or mines?
What is the significance of Article 21 in the Indian Constitution?
Article 15 prohibits discrimination on certain grounds. However, which groups can the State make special provisions for under this Article?
Which Article allows Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship and override previous articles on citizenship (Articles 5 to 10)?
What restrictions can the State impose on the right to freedom of speech under Article 19(2)?
answers: The official name of India according to Article 1 of the Constitution is "India, that is Bharat."
Article 14 guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons.
Article 17 of the Constitution abolishes "untouchability" and forbids its practice in any form.
The key ideals mentioned in the Preamble of the Constitution of India are Justice, Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity.
Parliament can alter the boundaries, area, or name of an existing State under Article 3 of the Constitution of India.
Children below the age of fourteen years are prohibited from working in hazardous industries like factories or mines.

Article 21 of the Indian Constitution guarantees the right to life and personal liberty, stating that no person shall be deprived of these rights except according to procedure established by law. It is a fundamental right that protects individuals against arbitrary actions of the state and has been interpreted to include a wide range of rights such as the right to privacy, right to a fair trial, right to livelihood, and right to a clean environment.

The State can make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes of citizens, Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and economically weaker sections of citizens (other than the classes mentioned above), including in matters of admission to educational institutions and reservation in services under the State.
Article 11 allows Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship and override previous articles on citizenship (Articles 5 to 10).

The State can impose reasonable restrictions on the right to freedom of speech in the interests of the sovereignty and integrity of India, the security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, or in relation to contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence.

questions: If my car is stolen, what case will it be in law?
If I am arrested without a warrant, is that legal?
If someone denies me a job because of my caste, is that allowed?
If the government takes my land for a project, can I stop it?
If my child is forced to work in a factory, is that legal?
If I am stopped from speaking at a protest, is that against my rights?
If a religious place stops me from entering because I'm a woman, is that constitutional?
If I change my religion, can the government stop me?
If the police torture someone in custody, what right is being violated?
If I'm denied admission to a public university because I'm from a backward community, can I do something?
answers: If your car is stolen, it will be a case of theft under criminal law.

Yes, you can be arrested without a warrant if the arrest is made according to the procedure established by law. However, after arrest, you must be informed of the grounds for arrest, allowed to consult a legal practitioner of your choice, and produced before the nearest magistrate within 24 hours, excluding travel time. Detention beyond this period requires the authority of a magistrate.
No, denying you a job because of your caste is not allowed. Discrimination in employment under the State on grounds of caste is prohibited.

You cannot stop the government from acquiring your land for a public purpose if the acquisition is done in accordance with the law in force. However, if your land is under personal cultivation and within the ceiling limit, the State cannot acquire it unless compensation at not less than market value is provided for the land, building, or structure.

No, it is not legal. No child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment. Forcing a child to work in a factory is prohibited and punishable by law.

If you are stopped from speaking at a protest, it may be against your right to freedom of speech and expression under Article 19(1)(a), unless the restriction is reasonable and falls under the exceptions provided by law, such as public order, morality, or security of the State.

If a religious place stops you from entering because you are a woman, it is generally unconstitutional, as no citizen shall, on grounds only of sex, be subject to any disability, liability, restriction, or condition with regard to access. However, an exception exists for religious or denominational institutions, where the law may require that the incumbent of an office or member of the governing body profess a particular religion or belong to a particular denomination. This exception does not extend to general entry or worship by women, so discrimination solely on the basis of sex is not constitutionally permitted.

No, the government cannot stop you from changing your religion. The right to freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate religion are guaranteed, subject only to public order, morality, and health.
The right being violated is the protection of life and personal liberty, as no person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.

No, you cannot be denied admission to a public university solely because you are from a backward community. The Constitution prohibits denial of admission on grounds only of religion, race, caste, or language. In fact, the State is permitted to make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes, including reservations in admissions. If you are denied admission solely for being from a backward community, it is unconstitutional and you can challenge this denial.

answers: Expenses for arthritis treatment at home would not be covered under Domiciliary Hospitalisation Cover, even if a doctor declares the treatment was medically required and a hospital bed is unavailable, because "Arthritis, gout and rheumatism" is explicitly listed as an exclusion under this benefit.
The prosthetic device is payable. The walker and lumbar belt are not payable.

**Claim Admissibility:**

1.  **Eligibility:** The insured's child is eligible for coverage as children above 18 years and up to 26 years are covered, provided they are unmarried, unemployed, and dependent.
2.  **Dental Coverage:** Dental treatment, including surgery, is covered if it is necessitated due to an accident and requires a minimum of 24 hours of hospitalization.

**Claim Process:**

1.  **Notification:**
    *   For emergency hospitalization, notify the TPA in writing within 24 hours from the date of emergency hospitalization or before discharge, whichever is earlier.
    *   For planned hospitalization, notify the TPA at least 48 hours prior to admission.
2.  **Cashless Facility (if applicable):**
    *   Cashless facility is available for treatment in network hospitals, subject to pre-authorization by the TPA.
    *   Upon admission, produce the ID card issued by the TPA at the hospital insurance desk.
    *   Complete and send the cashless request form to the TPA for pre-authorization.
    *   The TPA will issue a pre-authorization letter after verification.
    *   At discharge, verify and sign discharge papers and the final bill, and pay for non-medical and inadmissible expenses.
3.  **Reimbursement:**
    *   For non-network hospitals, payment must be made upfront.
    *   Submit necessary documents to the TPA within the prescribed time limit.
    *   **Time limits for submission of documents:**
        *   Where Cashless Facility has been authorized: Immediately after discharge.
        *   Reimbursement of hospitalization, daycare, and pre-hospitalization expenses: Within 15 (fifteen) days of the date of discharge from the hospital.
        *   Reimbursement of post-hospitalization expenses: Within 15 (fifteen) days from completion of post-hospitalization treatment.
4.  **Required Documents (for reimbursement):**
    *   Duly completed claim form
    *   Photo ID and Age proof
    *   Health Card, policy copy, photo ID, KYC documents
    *   Attending medical practitioner's / surgeon's certificate regarding diagnosis/nature of operation performed, along with date of diagnosis, investigation test reports, etc., supported by the prescription from the attending medical practitioner.
    *   Medical history of the patient as recorded (All previous consultation papers indicating history and treatment details for current ailment), bills (including breakup of charges) and payment receipts duly supported by the prescription from attending medical practitioner/hospital.
    *   Discharge certificate/summary from the hospital.
    *   Original final Hospital bill with detailed breakup with all original deposit and final payment receipt.
    *   Original invoice with payment receipt and implant stickers for all implants used during Surgeries (e.g., lens sticker and Invoice in cataract Surgery, stent invoice and sticker in Angioplasty Surgery).
    *   All original diagnostic reports (including imaging and laboratory) along with Medical Practitioner's prescription and invoice / bill with receipt from diagnostic center.
    *   All original medicine / pharmacy bills along with the Medical Practitioner's prescription.
    *   MLC / FIR copy in Accidental cases only.
    *   Copy of death summary and copy of death certificate (in death claims only).
    *   Pre and post-operative imaging reports.
    *   Copy of indoor case papers with nursing sheet detailing medical history of the Insured Person, treatment details and the Insured Person's progress.
    *   Cheque copy with name of proposer printed on the cheque leaf or copy of the first page of the bank passbook or the bank statement not later than 3 months.

For Intra Operative Neuro Monitoring (IONM), the expenses are limited up to the limit as specified in the Policy Schedule or Certificate of Insurance per policy period.

For ICU care, the policy schedule states that ICU/ICCU/HDU (per day limit) expenses are covered as "Actual Expenses Incurred." The critical care definition for an Intensive Care Unit (ICU) describes it as an identified section of a hospital equipped for continuous monitoring and treatment of critically ill patients, with ICU charges including expenses for ICU bed, general medical support services, monitoring devices, critical care nursing, and intensivist charges. While the definition of a hospital specifies a minimum of 15 in-patient beds in towns with a population of 1,000,000 or more, this is a criterion for a facility to be considered a hospital, not a specific limitation on ICU expenses based on city population.

To add a newly-adopted 3-year-old child as a dependent:

**Process:**
1.  The policyholder must apply for the addition of the child as an Insured Person.
2.  The application for cover must be accepted by the insurer.
3.  Additional premium on a pro-rata basis for the risk coverage duration for the child must be paid.
4.  The insurer will issue an endorsement confirming the addition of the child as an Insured Person.

**Circumstances for refusal:**
According to the eligibility clause, "The Employee/member's children between the age of 91 days and 18 years shall be covered provided either or both parents are covered concurrently." A 3-year-old child falls within this eligible age bracket.

The insurer may refuse cover if the application for cover is not accepted by them. General reasons for non-acceptance or policy voidance, as per the disclosure of information and fraud clauses, include:
*   Misrepresentation, misdescription, or non-disclosure of any material fact by the policyholder.
*   Fraudulent means or devices used by the Insured Person or anyone acting on their behalf to obtain any benefit under the policy.
*   Failure to pay the additional pro-rata premium or fulfill other terms and conditions of the policy.

For the day care cataract procedure and subsequent complications requiring 5 days of inpatient care in a non-network hospital:

**Claim Process for Day Care Cataract Procedure:**

*   **Claim Notification:**
    *   For planned day care treatment, notify the TPA at least 48 hours prior to admission.
    *   For emergency day care treatment, notify the TPA within 24 hours from the date of emergency hospitalization or before discharge, whichever is earlier.
*   **Document Requirements (for reimbursement from a non-network hospital):**
    *   Duly completed claim form
    *   Photo ID and Age proof
    *   Health Card, policy copy, photo ID, KYC documents
    *   Attending medical practitioner's / surgeon's certificate regarding diagnosis/ nature of operation performed, along with date of diagnosis, investigation test reports etc. supported by the prescription from the attending medical practitioner
    *   Medical history of the patient as recorded (All previous consultation papers indicating history and treatment details for current ailment), bills (including break up of charges) and payment receipts duly supported by the prescription from attending medical practitioner/ hospital
    *   Discharge certificate/ summary from the hospital
    *   Original final Hospital bill with detailed break-up with all original deposit and final payment receipt
    *   Original invoice with payment receipt and implant stickers for all implants used during Surgeries i.e. lens sticker and Invoice in cataract Surgery, stent invoice and sticker in Angioplasty Surgery
    *   All original diagnostic reports (including imaging and laboratory) along with Medical Practitioner's prescription and invoice / bill with receipt from diagnostic center
    *   All original medicine / pharmacy bills along with the Medical Practitioner's prescription
    *   MLC / FIR copy in Accidental cases only
    *   Copy of death summary and copy of death certificate (in death claims only)
    *   Pre and post-operative imaging reports
    *   Copy of indoor case papers with nursing sheet detailing medical history of the Insured Person, treatment details and the Insured Person's progress
    *   Cheque copy with name of proposer printed on the cheque leaf or copy of the first page of the bank passbook or the bank statement not later than 3 months
*   **Submission Timeline:** Within 15 days of the date of discharge from the hospital.

**Claim Process for Complications requiring 5 days of Inpatient Care (Relapse Event):**

*   **Relapse Consideration:** Since the complications occurred two weeks after discharge (within 45 days), this is considered a relapse and will be deemed part of the same claim as the initial cataract procedure.
*   **Claim Notification:**
    *   For emergency hospitalization due to complications, notify the TPA within 24 hours from the date of emergency hospitalization or before discharge, whichever is earlier.
    *   For planned hospitalization, notify the TPA at least 48 hours prior to admission.
*   **Document Requirements:** The same list of documents as for the initial day care procedure (as listed above) applies for reimbursement from a non-network hospital.
*   **Submission Timeline:** Within 15 days of the date of discharge from the hospital for the inpatient care.

The newborn's treatment expenses are eligible for a claim.

Here's the breakdown based on the policy:

1.  **New Born Baby Definition:** A "New Born Baby" is defined as a baby born during the Policy period and aged up to 90 days (Page 19, II. DEFINITIONS, 31). The newborn in this scenario falls within this definition.
2.  **New Born Baby Benefit Cover:** "New Born Babies will be accepted for cover... from birth if mother is covered and maternity cover is opted" (Page 27, B.Specific Terms and Clauses, 3. Eligibility, d). The mother had maternity cover, fulfilling this condition. Acceptance is subject to the limitations of the New Born Baby Benefit Cover, written notification on or before the last day of the month following the birth, and receipt of the agreed premium.
3.  **Maternity Expenses:** "Medical treatment expenses traceable to childbirth (including complicated deliveries and caesarean sections incurred during hospitalisation)" are covered (Page 20, II. DEFINITIONS, 23).
4.  **In-patient Hospitalisation Expenses Cover:** This includes "Charges for accommodation in ICU/CCU/HDU up to the category/limit specified in the Policy Schedule/ Certificate of Insurance or actual expenses incurred, whichever is less" (Page 22, A. Base Covers, 1.In-patient Hospitalisation Expenses Cover, B).
5.  **Maternity Exclusion (Code-Excl18):** This exclusion lists "Medical treatment expenses traceable to child birth (Including complicated deliveries and caesarean sections incurred during hospitalisation) except ectopic pregnancy" and "Expenses towards miscarriage (unless due to an accident)". The scenario of a newborn requiring intensive care after a complicated C-section is not excluded under this clause (Page 24, IV.PERMANENT EXCLUSIONS & WAITING PERIODS, B.Standard Permanent Exclusions, 18).

Yes, the provided documents should be sufficient.

Justification:
1.  **Medical Advice and Prescription:** The policy states that expenses are covered when incurred on the "written Medical Advice of a Medical Practitioner" and are for "Medically Necessary Treatment" which "must have been prescribed by a medical practitioner" (Page 22, A. Base Covers; Page 20, II. DEFINITIONS, A.Standard Definitions, 27.Medically Necessary Treatment). A "Medical Practitioner" is defined as a person holding a valid registration from the Medical Council of any State or Medical Council of India, or other specified councils, and entitled to practice medicine within their jurisdiction (Page 20, II. DEFINITIONS, A.Standard Definitions, 26.Medical Practitioner). A general practitioner falls under this definition, thus their prescription is acceptable.
2.  **Mental Healthcare Professional:** A "Clinical Psychologist" is explicitly defined as a "Mental Healthcare Professional" (Page 21, II. DEFINITIONS, B.Specific Definitions, 27.Mental Healthcare Professional). Therefore, a discharge summary certified by a registered Clinical Psychologist is a valid document from a recognized mental healthcare professional.
3.  **Claim Documents:** The required claim documents include an "Attending medical practitioner's / surgeon's certificate regarding diagnosis/ nature of operation performed, along with date of diagnosis, investigation test reports etc. supported by the prescription from the attending medical practitioner" and "Medical history of the patient as recorded... supported by the prescription from attending medical practitioner/ hospital" (Page 30, VI.CLAIM PROCEDURE, 5. Documents, i.iv. and i.v.). The general practitioner's prescription fulfills the requirement for medical advice from a Medical Practitioner, and the Clinical Psychologist's certified discharge summary provides the necessary supporting details from a qualified mental health professional.

Both ECG electrodes and gloves are admissible for reimbursement, subject to the following constraints:

*   **ECG ELECTRODES:** Payable. Up to 5 electrodes are required for every case visiting OT or ICU. For longer stays in ICU, a change may be required, and at least one set every second day is payable.
*   **GLOVES:** Only sterilized gloves are payable; unsterilized gloves are not payable.

Both the pre-hospitalization and post-hospitalization expenses can be claimed.

1.  **Pre-hospitalisation expenses**: The policy covers pre-hospitalisation medical expenses incurred up to **30 days** prior to admission (Page 2, Base Covers; Page 22, Clause III.A.3). Since the expenses occurred 18 days before admission, they fall within this limit.
2.  **Post-hospitalisation diagnostics and pharmacy expenses**: The policy covers post-hospitalisation medical expenses incurred up to **60 days** after discharge (Page 2, Base Covers; Page 22, Clause III.A.4). Since these expenses occurred 20 days after discharge, they fall within this limit.

Both are subject to the condition that an in-patient hospitalization claim for the same illness or injury has been accepted (Page 22, Clause III.A.3(i) and III.A.4(i)).

Based on the policy's definition of "Age or Aged" as the age of the Insured Person on their last birthday as of the date of commencement of the Policy, if a dependent child is 26 years old at the beginning of the coverage year, their coverage continues for the entire policy period.

Their eligibility for coverage would terminate at the end of that policy period, as they would be 27 years old (or older) at the time of the next policy commencement, exceeding the "up to the age of 26 years" eligibility criteria for dependent children. The deletion protocols related to ceasing to be a dependent would apply at the point of renewal, not mid-term due to turning 27 within the current policy period.

When the insured opts for a single private room costing more than the allowed room rent limit, and diagnostic and specialist fees are billed separately:

*   **Specialist fees:** These are considered "Associated Medical Expenses" and will be reimbursed in the same proportion as the admissible rate per day bears to the actual rate per day of Room Rent.
*   **Diagnostic fees:** These are an exception to "Associated Medical Expenses" and are therefore not subject to the proportionate deduction.

The relevant clause is **Note 1: Proportionate Clause** under **1. In-patient Hospitalisation Expenses Cover** on page 22, and the definition of **5. Associated Medical Expenses** on page 21.

If a claim is partly rejected due to lack of required documentation, the following course of action applies:

1.  **Deficiency in Documents**: If the deficiency in the necessary claim documents is not met or is partially met within 10 working days of the first intimation, the company will send a maximum of 3 reminders. The company may, at its sole discretion, deduct the amount of the claim for which deficiency is intimated and settle the claim if otherwise valid.
2.  **Final Rejection**: If the company decides to reject a claim, they will communicate the grounds for rejection/repudiation in writing within 15 (thirty) days from the receipt of the final document(s) or investigation report.
3.  **Contesting Final Rejection**: If the Insured Person desires to contest the final rejection, they may represent for reconsideration of the decision within 15 days from the date of receipt of the claims decision.
4.  **Grievance Procedure**: If the Insured Person is not satisfied with the redressal of grievance through the company's channels (website, toll-free, email, courier, or branch grievance cell), they may approach the office of the Insurance Ombudsman of the respective area/region as per Insurance Ombudsman Rules 2017. Grievances can also be lodged at the IRDAI Integrated Grievance Management System (https://igms.irda.gov.in/).

Yes, the claim is eligible.

The relevant category is **Day Care Treatment**.

Its requirements are:
i. undertaken under General or Local Anesthesia in a hospital/day care centre in less than 24 hours because of technological advancement, and
ii. which would have otherwise required a hospitalisation of more than 24 hours. Treatment normally taken on an out-patient basis is not included in the scope of this definition.

When the insured is hospitalized, for a hospital to qualify under this policy, the minimum infrastructure requirements are:

*   **For towns having a population of less than 1,000,000:**
    *   At least 10 in-patient beds.
*   **For all other places (including metropolitan areas):**
    *   At least 15 in-patient beds.

In addition to the bed count, for both types of locations, the hospital must also meet the following criteria:
*   Has qualified nursing staff under its employment round the clock.
*   Has qualified medical practitioner(s) in charge round the clock.
*   Has a fully equipped operation theatre of its own where surgical procedures are carried out.
*   Maintains daily records of patients and makes these accessible to the insurance company's authorized personnel.

Eligibility criteria for adding insured persons mid-policy for a group employer:

*   **New Employee**: Must be a newly appointed employee.
*   **Spouse**: Must be a newly wedded spouse of the employee.
*   **Sibling**: Must be an employee/member's sibling up to the age of 26 years, provided they are unmarried/unemployed and dependent.

Documentation necessary to process these additions:

*   Application for cover (accepted by the insurer)
*   Additional premium on pro-rata basis (received by the insurer)
*   Endorsement confirming the addition (issued by the insurer)

Robotic surgeries, including robotic assisted surgeries, for the treatment of malignancies are covered up to 50% of the Sum Insured (SI) per policy period. This coverage applies whether the procedure is performed as an in-patient or as part of day care treatment in a hospital.

For air ambulance evacuation with subsequent inpatient admission, the following steps and documentation are required:

**Pre-authorization:**
1.  The Insured Person must immediately notify the company either at their call center or in writing.
2.  Emergency medical evacuations require pre-authorization.
3.  The company's team of Specialists, in association with the Emergency assistance service provider, will determine the medical necessity of such evacuation or repatriation, after which it will be approved.

**Claims Assessment and Documentation:**
For claims assessment, the following original documents must be submitted:
*   Duly completed claim form
*   Photo ID and Age proof
*   Health Card, policy copy, photo ID, KYC documents
*   Attending medical practitioner's / surgeon's certificate regarding diagnosis/nature of operation performed, along with date of diagnosis, investigation test reports etc. supported by the prescription from the attending medical practitioner
*   Medical history of the patient as recorded (All previous consultation papers indicating history and treatment details for current ailment), bills (including break up of charges) and payment receipts duly supported by the prescription from attending medical practitioner/hospital
*   Discharge certificate/summary from the hospital
*   Original final Hospital bill with detailed break-up with all original deposit and final payment receipt
*   Original invoice with payment receipt and implant stickers for all implants used during Surgeries i.e. lens sticker and Invoice in cataract Surgery, stent invoice and sticker in Angioplasty Surgery
*   All original diagnostic reports (including imaging and laboratory) along with Medical Practitioner's prescription and invoice / bill with receipt from diagnostic center
*   All original medicine / pharmacy bills along with the Medical Practitioner's prescription
*   MLC / FIR copy in Accidental cases only
*   Copy of death summary and copy of death certificate (in death claims only)
*   Pre and post-operative imaging reports
*   Copy of indoor case papers with nursing sheet detailing medical history of the Insured Person, treatment details and the Insured Person's progress
*   Cheque copy with name of proposer printed on the cheque leaf or copy of the first page of the bank passbook or the bank statement not later than 3 months.

If an insured had prior continuous coverage under a different insurer and recently ported to this policy without any break, the waiting period for a specific illness like knee replacement due to osteoarthritis would be reduced to the extent of their prior coverage, as defined under the applicable norms on portability stipulated by IRDAI. The proposed Insured Person will get the accrued continuity benefits in waiting periods as per IRDAI guidelines on portability.

No, the expense for an imported medication not normally used in India as part of inpatient treatment will not be covered.

According to the policy:
*   **Unproven/Experimental Treatment (II. DEFINITIONS, A.Standard Definitions, 43):** This means "the treatment, including drug experimental therapy, which is not based on established medical practice in India, is treatment experimental or unproven."
*   **Unproven Treatments (IV.PERMANENT EXCLUSIONS & WAITING PERIODS, B.Standard Permanent Exclusions, 16):** "Expenses related to any unproven treatment, services and supplies for or in connection with any treatment. Unproven treatments are treatments, procedures or supplies that lack significant medical documentation to support their effectiveness."

Since the medication is "not normally used in India," it falls under the definition of "Unproven/Experimental Treatment," and expenses for such treatments are explicitly excluded.

For claims involving implanted devices such as cardiac stents, the required supporting documentation includes the original invoice with payment receipt and implant stickers.

If only a generic invoice (without an implant sticker) is provided, it will be considered a deficiency in the documents. The company will intimate this deficiency and may send up to three reminders. At its discretion, the company may decide to deduct the amount of the claim for which the deficiency is intimated and settle the claim if it is otherwise valid under the policy.

Home nursing charges qualify for reimbursement if the service is arranged by the Hospital for a Qualified Nurse to visit the patient's home to provide expert nursing services immediately after Hospital Treatment, for as long as is required by medical necessity. In either case, the Specialist who treated the patient must have recommended these services.

The required documentation for reimbursement is:
*   Bills from registered nursing service provider.

In a multi-policy scenario, if the available coverage under the primary policy is less than the admissible claim amount:
*   The primary Insurer shall seek the details of other available policies of the policyholder.
*   The primary Insurer shall coordinate with other Insurers to ensure settlement of the balance amount as per the policy conditions.
*   A written request for the same must be submitted by the Insured Person.

No, these expenses are not claimable.

According to the "Standard Permanent Exclusions" under "IV.PERMANENT EXCLUSIONS & WAITING PERIODS", specifically "4.Investigation & Evaluation (Code-Excl04)":
*   Expenses related to any admission primarily for diagnostics and evaluation purposes only are excluded.
*   Any diagnostic expenses which are not related or not incidental to the current diagnosis and treatment are excluded.

Since the hospitalization was solely for evaluation and diagnostics, and no treatment was decided upon, the expenses fall under these exclusions.

Any change of nomination is effective only when an endorsement on the policy is made. The policy does not specify a procedure for updating the nominee after the sudden demise of the previous nominee in the absence of any prior endorsement for nominee change. In such a case, if there is no subsisting nominee, the Company will pay the legal heirs or legal representatives of the policyholder.

Prostheses or medical appliances are not covered in the following scenarios:

1.  **Non-Medical Expenses:** When they are non-medical expenses, including convenience items for personal comfort, not consistent with or incidental to the diagnosis and treatment of the Illness/Injury for which the Insured Person was Hospitalised, such as ambulatory devices, walker, crutches, belts, collars, splints, slings, braces, stockings of any kind, diabetic footwear, glucometer/thermometer, and any medical equipment that is subsequently used at home, unless they form part of room expenses.
2.  **Specifically Listed as Not Payable (Annexure-I):**
    *   ARMSLING
    *   CERVICAL COLLAR
    *   SPLINT
    *   KNEE BRACES (LONG/ SHORT/ HINGED)
    *   KNEE IMMOBILIZER/SHOULDER IMMOBILIZER
    *   AMBULANCE COLLAR
    *   General cases for BELTS/ BRACES, SLINGS, LUMBO SACRAL BELT, ABDOMINAL BINDER when not for specific surgeries mentioned (e.g., thoracic or lumbar spine surgery for belts/braces, upper arm fractures for slings, lumbar spine surgery for lumbo sacral belt and abdominal binder).
3.  **Not Required Intra-operatively:** When they are not required intra-operatively for the Illness/Injury for which the Insured Person was Hospitalised.

The policy states that an AYUSH Day Care Centre must be "registered with the local authorities, wherever applicable" (II. DEFINITIONS, A. Standard Definitions, 3. AYUSH Day Care Centre). Similarly, a "Hospital" is defined as any institution "registered as a hospital with the local authorities" (II. DEFINITIONS, A. Standard Definitions, 16. Hospital). Since the AYUSH hospital is not registered locally, it does not meet the policy's definition of a covered facility, and therefore, expenses will not be reimbursed.

In the event of any change in the diagnosis, plan of Treatment, or cost of Treatment during Hospitalisation to the Insured Person, the Network Provider must obtain a fresh authorization letter from the insurer in accordance with the process described under clause V.4.
The Pre-Hospitalisation Medical Expenses Cover claim shall be processed only after the decision of the main Hospitalisation claim.

If a claim is made with forged documents or if any fraudulent means or devices are used, all benefits under the policy and the premium paid shall be forfeited.

If there is a deficiency in necessary claim documents, and it is not met after a maximum of three reminders, the company may, at its sole discretion, deduct the amount of the claim for which deficiency is intimated and settle the claim if it is otherwise valid under the Policy.

Reimbursement for expenses not related to hospitalization is generally not covered. The policy primarily covers medical expenses incurred due to hospitalization, pre-hospitalization, and post-hospitalization.

Specifically, the policy excludes:
*   Expenses related to any admission primarily for diagnostics and evaluation purposes only.
*   Any diagnostic expenses which are not related or incidental to the current diagnosis and treatment.
*   Expenses related to any admission primarily for enforced bed rest and not for receiving treatment, including custodial care and services for terminally ill people.
*   Conditions for which treatment could have been done on an out-patient basis without any hospitalization.

    You must inform the Company immediately in writing of any change in the address (clause 5.34).

**Critical Illness Survival Benefit Details:**
The Life Hardship Survival Benefit Plan is payable if an Insured Person is diagnosed with one of the 11 specified critical illnesses and a claim is admissible under the Policy. This benefit is not available for illnesses the Insured Person is already suffering from at the time of opting for this cover for the first time. The benefit is paid only once during the lifetime of the Insured Person for a particular disease.

*   **Amount payable on survival for 180 days and above from the date of discharge from the Hospital (if more than one Hospitalization is involved):**

    *   Gold, Diamond, Platinum Plans: 10% of the Sum Insured
*   **Amount payable on survival for 270 days and above from the date of discharge from the Hospital (if more than one Hospitalization is involved):**
    *   Silver Plan: 10% of the Sum Insured
    *   Gold, Diamond, Platinum Plans: 15% of the Sum Insured

For pre-authorization of air ambulance transfer following a road accident, the process is as follows:
Cashless Access Services are available through the Company/TPA if admission is to a network Hospital/Nursing Home and is subject to pre-admission authorization. The Company/TPA will verify eligibility based on medical details and information from the Insured Person/Network Hospital/Nursing Home and, if satisfied, will issue a pre-authorization letter/guarantee of payment. The Turn Around Time (TAT) for pre-authorization of cashless facility is immediately, but not later than one hour from the receipt of the request. The air ambulance cover is available for Platinum Plan only, up to 5% of the policy sum insured, for life-threatening medical emergencies where ground transportation is not feasible, necessary medical treatment is unavailable at the location, it is prescribed by a Medical Practitioner, the insured person is in India, and it is for Cardio-Vascular diseases, Central nervous system related cases, or Accidental Trauma Cases. This cover can be availed only once during the entire policy lifetime, and the air ambulance must be duly licensed.

For upgrading from Silver to Diamond plan with enhanced sum insured:
As per section 5.38, if there are no claims reported in the two immediate preceding Policy Periods, a change to the next Plan (Silver to Gold, Gold to Diamond, and Diamond to Platinum) at the initial Sum Insured slab, or two steps higher from the current Sum Insured, whichever is more, is allowed at the option of the Insured. No increase in Sum Insured is allowed in policies where there are claims reported in two successive Policy Periods.

questions: What is the daily limit for room, boarding, and nursing expenses for a sum insured of 4 lakhs?
What is the maximum daily ICU expense coverage for a sum insured of 8 lakhs?
If the sum insured is 12 lakhs, how are the room, boarding, and nursing expenses covered?
answers: For a sum insured of 4 lakhs, which falls under the "Up to 5 lakhs" slab, the daily limit for room, boarding, and nursing expenses is a Single Room up to 1% of the Sum Insured, with a maximum of Rs 5,000/- per day. Therefore, for 4 lakhs, the limit is 1% of 4 lakhs, which is Rs. 4,000/- per day.
For a sum insured of 8 lakhs, the maximum daily Intensive Care Unit (ICU) expense coverage is up to Rs. 20,000/- per day.
If the sum insured is 12 lakhs, the room, boarding, and nursing expenses are covered as "Actuals Expenses" as per section 3.18 for "Above 10 lakhs" sum insured slabs.

questions: I have raised a claim for hospitalization for Rs 200,000 with HDFC, and it's approved. My total expenses are Rs 250,000. Can I raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with you?
answers: No, you cannot raise the remaining Rs 50,000 with another insurer for the same hospitalization if the total claim has already been settled and approved for Rs 200,000 by HDFC. The policy covers expenses up to the sum insured per policy, and claims cannot be split or duplicated across insurers for the same event beyond the actual expenses incurred and the sum insured limits. If your sum insured with HDFC is Rs 200,000 and they have paid that amount, you cannot claim the excess with another insurer unless you have a separate policy with a different sum insured and follow contribution rules.

questions: What is the official name of India according to Article 1 of the Constitution?
Which Article guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons?
What is abolished by Article 17 of the Constitution?
What are the key ideals mentioned in the Preamble of the Constitution of India?
Under which Article can Parliament alter the boundaries, area, or name of an existing State?
According to Article 24, children below what age are prohibited from working in hazardous industries like factories or mines?
What is the significance of Article 21 in the Indian Constitution?
Article 15 prohibits discrimination on certain grounds. However, which groups can the State make special provisions for under this Article?
Which Article allows Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship and override previous articles on citizenship (Articles 5 to 10)?
What restrictions can the State impose on the right to freedom of speech under Article 19(2)?
answers: The official name of India according to Article 1 of the Constitution is "India, that is Bharat."
Article 14 guarantees equality before the law and equal protection of laws to all persons.
Article 17 of the Constitution abolishes "untouchability" and forbids its practice in any form.
The key ideals mentioned in the Preamble of the Constitution of India are Justice, Liberty, Equality, and Fraternity.
Parliament can alter the boundaries, area, or name of an existing State under Article 3 of the Constitution of India.
Children below the age of fourteen years are prohibited from working in hazardous industries like factories or mines.

Article 21 of the Indian Constitution guarantees the right to life and personal liberty, stating that no person shall be deprived of these rights except according to procedure established by law. It is a fundamental right that protects individuals against arbitrary actions of the state and has been interpreted to include a wide range of rights such as the right to privacy, right to a fair trial, right to livelihood, and right to a clean environment.

The State can make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes of citizens, Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and economically weaker sections of citizens (other than the classes mentioned above), including in matters of admission to educational institutions and reservation in services under the State.
Article 11 allows Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship and override previous articles on citizenship (Articles 5 to 10).

The State can impose reasonable restrictions on the right to freedom of speech in the interests of the sovereignty and integrity of India, the security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, or in relation to contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to an offence.

questions: If my car is stolen, what case will it be in law?
If I am arrested without a warrant, is that legal?
If someone denies me a job because of my caste, is that allowed?
If the government takes my land for a project, can I stop it?
If my child is forced to work in a factory, is that legal?
If I am stopped from speaking at a protest, is that against my rights?
If a religious place stops me from entering because I'm a woman, is that constitutional?
If I change my religion, can the government stop me?
If the police torture someone in custody, what right is being violated?
If I'm denied admission to a public university because I'm from a backward community, can I do something?
answers: If your car is stolen, it will be a case of theft under criminal law.

Yes, you can be arrested without a warrant if the arrest is made according to the procedure established by law. However, after arrest, you must be informed of the grounds for arrest, allowed to consult a legal practitioner of your choice, and produced before the nearest magistrate within 24 hours, excluding travel time. Detention beyond this period requires the authority of a magistrate.
No, denying you a job because of your caste is not allowed. Discrimination in employment under the State on grounds of caste is prohibited.

You cannot stop the government from acquiring your land for a public purpose if the acquisition is done in accordance with the law in force. However, if your land is under personal cultivation and within the ceiling limit, the State cannot acquire it unless compensation at not less than market value is provided for the land, building, or structure.

No, it is not legal. No child below the age of fourteen years shall be employed to work in any factory or mine or engaged in any other hazardous employment. Forcing a child to work in a factory is prohibited and punishable by law.

If you are stopped from speaking at a protest, it may be against your right to freedom of speech and expression under Article 19(1)(a), unless the restriction is reasonable and falls under the exceptions provided by law, such as public order, morality, or security of the State.

If a religious place stops you from entering because you are a woman, it is generally unconstitutional, as no citizen shall, on grounds only of sex, be subject to any disability, liability, restriction, or condition with regard to access. However, an exception exists for religious or denominational institutions, where the law may require that the incumbent of an office or member of the governing body profess a particular religion or belong to a particular denomination. This exception does not extend to general entry or worship by women, so discrimination solely on the basis of sex is not constitutionally permitted.

No, the government cannot stop you from changing your religion. The right to freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate religion are guaranteed, subject only to public order, morality, and health.
The right being violated is the protection of life and personal liberty, as no person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.

No, you cannot be denied admission to a public university solely because you are from a backward community. The Constitution prohibits denial of admission on grounds only of religion, race, caste, or language. In fact, the State is permitted to make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes, including reservations in admissions. If you are denied admission solely for being from a backward community, it is unconstitutional and you can challenge this denial.
